block.p: The top-ranking Air Force officer was abruptly dismissed by Defense Secretary Dick Cheney for publicly discussing Pentagon contingency plans for waging a war against Iraq, including specific targets for American air strikes.
Cheney has staked out authority at Pentagon
Air blockade of Iraq is backed by President Bush
U.N. drafts plan to tighten embargo of Iraq
Iraqi forces seized Kuwaiti men between the ages of 17 and 35 as they tried to cross the border between Kuwait and Saudi Arabia. The Kuwaitis reacted with a sense of panic and stunned disbelief.
Arab radicals say they will avenge Iraq
A mother's plea to Hussein frees her son
Israeli says crisis has eroded Israel's military situation
The role of women in the military has changed drastically. Never before have so many women held so many types of jobs - and never before have so many husbands and children been left behind.
A modern missionary in Africa, Vangu Tsumbu, runs a highly successful AIDS-prevention program. He uses social marketing techniques to distribute condoms.
Cooperation by prostitutes in Kenya prevents AIDS cases
The confusion over economic reform in the Soviet Union was compounded by President Gorbachev, who proposed a referendum on the question of whether the private ownership of land should be legalized.
Walesa declares he will run for President of Poland
Hungary's chief begins to accept popularity

A new law published in Nicaragua grants Sandinista commanders broad permanent authority over the structure and operations of the country's large military forces, even though the Sandinista Front lost power six months ago.
Intense street battles rage in Monrovia
Aquino asks Americans to quit Filipino bases
Australia's chief watches his support ebb
Journal: A tale of the saintly (and the smart)

The nominee for the Supreme Court, Judge David H. Souter, seemed to endorse a more activist court on his last day of Senate testimony. He said he could not think of one recent instance in which the Court had ''improperly created new rights.''

Mayor Barry will not be retried on the 12 drug and perjury charges that a jury was unable to resolve last month, prosecutors said. They said a new trial would be unlikely to achieve ''substantially more.''
A string of courtroom reverses suffered by the Justice Department, like the divided verdict in the trial of Mayor Barry, has raised questions about the Government's fairness to well-known defendants.
Bush calls on negotiators to adopt cut in capital gains tax
Washington Talk: Bicycles get a day in the sun
Exxon's second summer in Alaska cleaning the mess from the nation's worst oil spill has ended with praise for how much was accomplished but discord over what was not.

A Pentagon program to acquire land has been suspended, following stiff resistance from farmers, ranchers and environmentalists. The program would have added 4.5 million acres to the 25 million acres now managed by the military.
Contract enhancing job security is agreed on by union and G.M.
Veterans chief apologizes for use of ethnic slur
The president of Boston University, John R. Silber, has thrown the Democratic primary for governor of Massachusetts into turmoil with a provacative remark about blacks and attacks on the news media.
Oklahoma vote to test drive to curb lawmakers' tenure
Study finds Jews split on marriage
Academy of Sciences urges changes in meat inspection

A young Bronx man killed a man who he believed had attacked his mother, the police said. Victor Lopez, 18 years old, has been charged with manslaughter, and his mother, Maria, says she has lost her battle to keep her children away from trouble.

As many as 3,100 new prison beds should be added to Rikers Island, the New York City Correction Commissioner said. The beds would handle what he said would be an increase in prisoners resulting from the addition of 5,000 police officers.
Watkins family endorses a plan to hire more police
Businesses offer aid to Dinkins to combat crime
A probation officer is taken hostage in Manhattan courthouse
New York City's Police Department must enforce a court order to keep black-led demonstrators at least 50 feet away from two Korean grocery stores in Brooklyn, an appellate court ruled.
Jury selection begins in another Bensonhurst trial
Members of the Newspaper Guild at The New York Post overwhelmingly approved an agreement that will keep the paper alive but slash their salaries 20 percent.
A handsome New Jersey community has been a favorite backdrop for 15 years for film companies making television commercials. But now the mayor of the community wants to ban the filming completely.
A poll finds New Yorkers are not blaming Cuomo for their woes
Ads by London jab at Cuomo and Rinfret as two of a kind
State panel releases plan for park along the Hudson
New York's welfare rolls up for first time in seven years
Testing troubles for anti-missile defense program
What would an increase in carbon dioxide mean for plants?
An untouched tribe collides with civilization
The Doctor's World: The value of a business degree
Proposed dam on a Ganges tributary raises concerns
National Endowment for the Arts supports pledge
Word and Image: The perplexing Emmys
Baseball: $102.5 million award in collusion case
The races with no starting lines
Mets in race: to re-sign Strawberry
Appeals court overturns conviction of agents
Golf: Cypress Point drops PGA Tour event
A. M. Rosenthal: Dumping on David
Russell Baker: Just the fax, Ar
Reginald A. Boddie: Apartheid at Virginia Beach
